From the photos, the building doesn't look very old. Wouldn't that mean that some form of temporary fire barriers were installed between floors and apartments to help slow the spread of a fire from one apartment? Wouldn't each floor have at least one working fire extinguisher that a resident could use to fight a fire in an apartment until professional help arrives? In this day and age with all the protections available, such a fire should not happen. Either someone cut corners in the fire safety of the building or this is a severe case of arson on a horrible level.

Questions. Is there some sort of local building regulation requiring smoke/fire alarms and sprinkler system in such buildings? Does this building have gas for heat and cooking or is it an all electric building? If it's an all electric building, I don't understand how a fire from one apartment could have gotten out of control so quickly?

It was built in 74 ( according to the report ) and yes it would have a gas mains running through it, as for the alarms, they should have been installed by all council owned properties, as for the private ones, I don't know
Sounds like the plastic cladding made it worse too

It'll have lif shafts and stair wells, perfect fire conduits, it'll concentrate and superheat with the vertical channels feeding air to the flames - or something lime that, ie perfect storm

Maybe itll take a tragedy like this to see tge end of tbese awful, ugly, dangerous out of date battery housing blocks in this country.
Keith 'kitkatman' Nichol 10 million pound refurb of this building just last year,,,,,,new external cladding seems to be suspect

Rich Lount I work at an 11 story building. Except for one two story stair, all stairwells have doors at every floor access and my building was built in the 1960s. We also have a sprinkler system with booster pumps tested every week. Just the sprinkler system alone would have prevented this tragedy. Building owners don't like to spend money on sprinklers because of the cost of installing and maintaining the system properly. In the long run, it saves money on insurance and repairs from fires. A well designed system will automatically notify local fire department of a sprinkler head activating. If the fire alarm system is set up with modern technology, they would activate all the alarms either on the floor or in the whole building, depending on design and purpose, as well as notifying local fire departments. This being an apartment building, I'd leave the smoke detectors inside the individual apartments connected but separate from activating the rest of the building. But put smoke alarms in the hallway and if one of those activates, they activate all alarms on that floor as well as the floors above and below.
